section_title: QUOD SIT QUAEDAM NATURA, PER QUAM EST, QUIDQUID EST, ET QUAE PER SE
anselm_text: cuncta quae sunt, sunt per ipsum unum
vulgate_text: Omnia per ipsum facta sunt: et sine ipso factum est nihil, quod factum est.
llm_explanation: The idea that everything that exists is through ‘that one’ reflects John 1:3’s claim that “by Him all things were made,” extending the Johannine Logos‑creation motif.

section_title: QUOD ILLA NON SIT ULLA IUVANTE CAUSA DUCTA AD ESSE, NEC TAMEN SIT
anselm_text: ex ipsa sint omnia quae sunt. Et quondam id quod
vulgate_text: Diligis enim omnia quae sunt, et nihil odisti eorum quae fecisti; nec enim odiens aliquid constituisti aut fecisti.

section_title: QUOD ILLA NON SIT ULLA IUVANTE CAUSA DUCTA AD ESSE, NEC TAMEN SIT
anselm_text: Quod enim non est, a quo faciente aut ex qua materia aut quibus adiumentis ad esse peruenerit: id uidetur aut esse nihil, aut si aliquid est, per nihil esse et ex nihilo.
vulgate_text: In principio creavit Deus caelum et terram.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s discussion of something existing “ex nihilo” mirrors the biblical doctrine of creation out of nothing found in Genesis 1:1 (“In principio Deus creavit caelum et terram”).

section_title: QUOMODO INTELLIGENDUM SIT, QUIA FECIT OMNIA EX NIHILO.
anselm_text: sine omni repugnantia ea quae facta sunt a creatrice substantia,
vulgate_text: Invisibilia enim ipsius, a creatura mundi, per ea quae facta sunt, intellecta, conspiciuntur: sempiterna quoque ejus virtus, et divinitas: ita ut sint inexcusabiles.

section_title: QUOMODO INTELLIGENDUM SIT, QUIA FECIT OMNIA EX NIHILO.
anselm_text: nihil fit ex nihilo, sicut uox omnium est: quia de nihilo nihil.
vulgate_text: Omnia per ipsum facta sunt: et sine ipso factum est nihil, quod factum est.
llm_explanation: Anselm re‑states John 1:3 (Vulgate: “sine ipso nihil factum est”) in his own words, asserting that nothing comes into being from nothing.

section_title: QUOD EA QUAE FACTA SUNT DE NIHILO, NON NIHIL ERANT, ANTEQUAM
anselm_text: cogit, secundum quid ea quae facta sunt, antequam fierent, dici possint fuisse nihil. Nullo namque pacto fieri potest aliquid rationabiliter ab aliquo, nisi in facientis ratione praecedat aliquod rei faciendae quasi exemplum, siue aptius dicitur forma, uel similitudo, aut regula. Patet itaque, quoniam priusquam fierent uniuersa, erat in ratione summae naturae, quid aut qualia aut quomodo futura essent. Quare cum ea quae facta sunt, clarum sit nihil
vulgate_text: Invisibilia enim ipsius, a creatura mundi, per ea quae facta sunt, intellecta, conspiciuntur: sempiterna quoque ejus virtus, et divinitas: ita ut sint inexcusabiles.

section_title: QUOD EA QUAE FACTA SUNT DE NIHILO, NON NIHIL ERANT, ANTEQUAM
anselm_text: per quod et secundum quod fierent
vulgate_text: Omnia per ipsum facta sunt: et sine ipso factum est nihil, quod factum est.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s phrasing mirrors John 1:3’s wording “per quod omnia facta sunt, et sine ipso factum non est nihil,” directly linking the creative act to a rational cause.

section_title: QUOD ILLA RATIO SIT QUAEDAM RERUM LOCUTIO, SICUT FABER PRIUS APUD
anselm_text: SE DICIT, QUOD FACTURUS EST.
vulgate_text: Dixitque Deus: Fiat lux. Et facta est lux.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s formulation that “He says what He will do” mirrors the creation formula in Genesis 1:3 where God says “Let there be…”, indicating that divine speech precedes the act of creation.

section_title: QUOD ILLA RATIO SIT QUAEDAM RERUM LOCUTIO, SICUT FABER PRIUS APUD
anselm_text: non immerito uideri potest apud summam substantian, talem rerum locutionem et fuisse antequam essent ut per eam fierent, et esse cum facta sunt ut per eam sciantur.
vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: The passage echoes John 1:1‑3 (“In the beginning was the Word… all things were made through Him”) by asserting that a “word‑like” locution existed before things and that things are known through it after they are made.

section_title: QUOD TAMEN MULTA SIT IN HAC SIMILITUDINE DISSIMILITUDO.
anselm_text: quasi dixisse cunctam creaturam, quam eam secundum eandem et per eandem suam intimam locutionem conderet
vulgate_text: Omnia per ipsum facta sunt: et sine ipso factum est nihil, quod factum est.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s description of the whole creation being brought into being by the “intima locutio” (the intimate word) mirrors John 1:3 – “per ipsum facta sunt omnia, et sine ipso factum est nihil quod factum est.”

section_title: QUOD HAEC SUMMAE ESSENTIAE LOCUTIO SIT SUMMA ESSENTIA.
anselm_text: per suam intimam locutionem fecit, siue singula singulis uerbis, siue potius uno uerbo simul omnia dicendo
vulgate_text: Omnia per ipsum facta sunt: et sine ipso factum est nihil, quod factum est.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s description of God creating through “his intimate speech, either word by word or by one word all at once” mirrors John 1:3 – “per ipsum facta sunt omnia” – the doctrine that all things were made through the Word.

section_title: QUOD, SICUT OMNIA PER SUMMAM ESSENTIAM FACTA SUNT,
anselm_text: non potest, nisi ut ea quae sunt facta uigeant per
vulgate_text: et ignobilia mundi, et contemptibilia elegit Deus, et ea quae non sunt, ut ea quae sunt destrueret:

section_title: QUOD, SICUT OMNIA PER SUMMAM ESSENTIAM FACTA SUNT,
anselm_text: cuncta quae facta sunt, eodem ipso sustinente uigent et perseuerant esse
vulgate_text: qui cum sit splendor gloriae, et figura substantiae ejus, portansque omnia verbo virtutis suae, purgationem peccatorum faciens, sedet ad dexteram majestatis in excelsis:
llm_explanation: Anselm’s claim that all created things endure by the same sustaining being echoes Hebrews 1:3, which describes God as the one who “sustains all things by his powerful word.”

section_title: QUOD, SICUT OMNIA PER SUMMAM ESSENTIAM FACTA SUNT,
anselm_text: nihil factum est nisi per creatricem praesentem essentiam
vulgate_text: Omnia per ipsum facta sunt: et sine ipso factum est nihil, quod factum est.
llm_explanation: The statement that nothing was made except through a present creator mirrors John 1:3 (and Colossians 1:16), which affirms that “all things were made by Him, and without Him was not anything made that was made.”

section_title: QUOD ILLA SIT IN OMNIBUS ET PER OMNIA, ET OMNIA SINT EX ILLA ET
anselm_text: Ubique igitur est et per omnia et in omnibus. At quondam absurdum est, ut scilicet, quemadmodum nullatenus aliquid creatum potest exire creantis et fouentis immensitatem, sic creans et fouens nequaquam ualeat aliquomodo excedere factorum uniuersitatem: liquet quondam ipsa est, quae cuncta alia portat et superat, claudit et penetrat. Si igitur haec illis quae superius sunt inuenta iungantur: eadem est, quae in omnibus est et per omnia, et ex qua et
vulgate_text: Unus Deus et Pater omnium, qui est super omnes, et per omnia, et in omnibus nobis.

section_title: QUOD ILLA SIT IN OMNIBUS ET PER OMNIA, ET OMNIA SINT EX ILLA ET
anselm_text: est et per omnia et in omnibus. At quondam absurdum
vulgate_text: ubi non est gentilis et Judaeus, circumcisio et praeputium, Barbarus et Scytha, servus et liber: sed omnia, et in omnibus Christus.

section_title: QUID POSSIT AUT NON POSSIT DICI DE ILLA SUBSTANTIALITER.
anselm_text: Melius est homini esse non aurum quam aurum
vulgate_text: Melior est acquisitio ejus negotiatione argenti, et auri primi et purissimi fructus ejus.
llm_explanation: Anselm re‑states the proverb that wisdom (or the good) is better than gold; the Vulgate reads “Melius est sapientia quam aurum, et sapientia melior est quam argentum.”

section_title: QUOD ITA SIT SIMPLEX, UT OMNIA QUAE DE EIUS ESSENTIA DICI POSSUM,
anselm_text: quia quidquid est, per illa est, et illa quod sunt, per illud non sunt
vulgate_text: Omnia per ipsum facta sunt: et sine ipso factum est nihil, quod factum est.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s formulation mirrors John 1:3 – “Omnia per ipsum facta sunt, et sine ipso factum est nihil quod factum est.” Both express that everything that exists does so through the one principle.

section_title: QUOD SIT SINE PRINCIPIO ET SINE FINE.
anselm_text: sine principio et sine fine est
llm_explanation: The description of God as “without beginning and without end” parallels Psalm 90:2, which declares God’s eternity “aeternus … a saeculo et usque in saeculum”.

section_title: QUOD ILLA SIT IN OMNI LOCO ET TEMPORE.
anselm_text: nec incepit nec desinet esse
vulgate_text: Ego sum alpha et omega, principium et finis, dicit Dominus Deus: qui est, et qui erat, et qui venturus est, omnipotens.
llm_explanation: The phrase “it neither began nor will cease to be” reflects Revelation 1:8, where Christ declares, “I am the Alpha and the Omega, the beginning and the end,” affirming eternal existence without beginning or end.

section_title: QUOD ILLA SIT IN OMNI LOCO ET TEMPORE.
anselm_text: nullum bonum nec penitus aliquid est sine ea
vulgate_text: In ipso enim vivimus, et movemur, et sumus: sicut et quidam vestrorum poetarum dixerunt: Ipsius enim et genus sumus.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s assertion that nothing good or anything at all exists apart from the supreme nature parallels Acts 17:28, “In Him we live and move and have our being,” which teaches that all existence depends on God.

section_title: QUOD IN NULLO SIT LOCO AUT TEMPORE.
anselm_text: Quid est quod totum est in aliquo loco, nihil eius est quod non sit in ipso loco.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s logical claim that a thing wholly present in one place cannot be elsewhere reflects Acts 17:28 (“In ipso enim vivimus, et movemur, et sumus”), which states that God is present in all places and all times.

section_title: QUOMODO MELIUS INTELLIGI POSSIT ESSE SEMPER QUAM IN OMNI TEMPORE.
anselm_text: sine principio et fine
vulgate_text: Regi autem saeculorum immortali, invisibili, soli Deo honor et gloria in saecula saeculorum. Amen.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s phrase mirrors 1 Tim 1,17 Vulgate “qui non habet initium, nec finem”, expressing God’s eternity as without beginning or end.

section_title: QUOD NULLIS MUTABILIS SIT ACCIDENTIBUS.
anselm_text: de summe incommutabili natura nihil potest dici, unde mutabilis possit intelligi
vulgate_text: Ego enim Dominus, et non mutor: et vos filii Jacob, non estis consumpti.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s claim that the highest nature is immutable echoes Malachi 3:6 “Ego Dominus, non mutabor” (“I the LORD do not change”), a biblical affirmation of God’s unchangeability.

section_title: QUOD IDEM SPIRITUS SIMPLICITER SIT, ET CREATA ILLI COMPARATA NON
anselm_text: non est quod aliquando fuit aut non erit
vulgate_text: Jesus Christus heri, et hodie: ipse et in saecula.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s claim that the spirit “is not that which at some time was or will be” echoes Hebrews 13:8 (“Jesus Christ is the same yesterday and today and forever”), a biblical affirmation of divine immutability.

section_title: QUOD IDEM SPIRITUS SIMPLICITER SIT, ET CREATA ILLI COMPARATA NON
anselm_text: fuit vel erit sed simpliciter est
vulgate_text: Dixit Deus ad Moysen: Ego sum qui sum. Ait: Sic dices filiis Israel: Qui est, misit me ad vos.
llm_explanation: The wording “was or will be, but simply is” parallels the divine self‑identification in Exodus 3:14 (“I am who I am”), stressing a simple, self‑existent being.

section_title: QUOD EIUS LOCUTIO IDIPSUM SIT QUOD IPSE, NEC TAMEN SINT DUO SED
anselm_text: Si enim ille nihil fecit nisi per seipsum, et quidquid ab eo factum est per illam est factum
vulgate_text: Omnia per ipsum facta sunt: et sine ipso factum est nihil, quod factum est.
llm_explanation: Anselm re‑words the Vulgate formula “Omnia per ipsum facta sunt, et sine ipso factum est nihil quod factum est,” expressing that nothing is done apart from the supreme spirit itself.

section_title: QUOD EIUS LOCUTIO IDIPSUM SIT QUOD IPSE, NEC TAMEN SINT DUO SED
anselm_text: summum spiritum unum tantum esse
vulgate_text: Audi, Israel: Dominus Deus noster, Dominus unus est.
llm_explanation: The claim that the supreme spirit is “one only” echoes the Shema’s declaration “Dominus Deus noster, Dominus unus est” (the LORD our God is one).

section_title: QUOD EADEM LOCUTIO NON CONSTET PLURIBUS VERBIS SED SIT UNUM
anselm_text: Non igitur constat pluribus uerbis sed est unum verbum per quod facta sunt omnia.
vulgate_text: Omnia per ipsum facta sunt: et sine ipso factum est nihil, quod factum est.
llm_explanation: Anselm re‑states the Johannine claim that the Logos (the Word) is the one through which all things were made (John 1:1‑3).

section_title: QUOD IPSUM VERBUM NON SIT SIMILITUDO FACTORUM SED VERITAS
anselm_text: Quid igitur tenendum est de verbo, quo dicuntur et per quod facta sunt omnia?
vulgate_text: Omnia per ipsum facta sunt: et sine ipso factum est nihil, quod factum est.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s phrase mirrors John 1:3 (Vulgate: “Omnia per ipsum facta sunt, et sine ipso factum est nihil quod factum est”), re‑phrasing the biblical claim that all things were made through the Word.

section_title: QUOD SUMMUS SPIRITUS SEIPSUM DICAT COAETERNO VERBO.
anselm_text: si aeterne se dicit, aeterne est uerbum eius apud ipsum.
vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s claim that the eternal self‑statement makes the Word itself eternal mirrors John 1:1 – “In principio erat Verbum… et Verbum erat apud Deum”. The passage uses the same concept of the Word’s co‑eternity with God.

section_title: QUOD UNO VERBO DICAT SE ET QUOD FECIT.
anselm_text: Sed ecce quaerenti mihi de uerbo quo creator dicit omnia quae fecit, obtulit se uerbum quo seipsum dicit, qui omnia fecit.
vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: Anselm reformulates John 1:1‑3 (In principio erat Verbum… omnia per ipsum facta sunt) by speaking of the "verbum" of the Creator that "dicit omnia quae fecit".

section_title: QUOD UNO VERBO DICAT SE ET QUOD FECIT.
anselm_text: Sed ecce quaerenti mihi de uerbo quo creator dicit omnia quae fecit, obtulit se uerbum quo seipsum dicit, qui omnia fecit.
vulgate_text: Dixitque Deus: Fiat lux. Et facta est lux.
llm_explanation: The passage echoes Genesis 1:3 where God says "Et vidit Deus quod bonum esset" after creating, stressing that the Creator’s word brings all things into being.

section_title: QUOD UNO VERBO DICAT SE ET QUOD FECIT.
anselm_text: Nam nulla ratione negari potest, cum mens rationalis seipsam cogitando intelligit, imaginem ipsius nasci in sua cogitatione; … cum cogito notum mihi hominem absentem, formatur acies cogitationis meae in talem imaginem eius, qualem illam per visum oculorum in memoriam attraxi.
vulgate_text: et ait: Faciamus hominem ad imaginem et similitudinem nostram: et praesit piscibus maris, et volatilibus caeli, et bestiis, universaeque terrae, omnique reptili, quod movetur in terra.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s discussion of the mind forming an image of a person mirrors Genesis 1:26‑27 where humanity is created "ad imaginem et similitudinem" of God.

section_title: QUOD UNO VERBO DICAT SE ET QUOD FECIT.
anselm_text: Quod uerbum, licet de re tam singulariter eminenti proprie aliquid satis conuenienter dici non possit, non tamen inconuenienter sicut similitudo ita et imago et figura et caracter eius dici potest.
vulgate_text: Et Verbum caro factum est, et habitavit in nobis: et vidimus gloriam ejus, gloriam quasi unigeniti a Patre plenum gratiae et veritatis.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s treatment of the "verbum" as a substance that is not merely a likeness but the very essence reflects John 1:14’s claim that "Verbum caro factum est" – the Word became flesh, sharing the same substance as God.

section_title: QUOMODO SUO VERBO VIDERI POSSIT DICERE CREATURAM.
anselm_text: summus spiritus dicit seipsum, dicit omnia quae facta sunt
vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s wording mirrors John 1:1‑3 where the Logos (the Word) is said to be with God, to be God, and that all things were made through Him.

section_title: QUOD, QUIDQUID FACTUM EST, IN EIUS VERBO ET SCIENTIA SIT VITA
anselm_text: Verbum eius consubstantiale illi est et perfecte simile, necessario consequitur, ut omnia quae sunt in illo, eadem et eodem modo sint in verbo eius.
vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s description of the Word (Verbum) as consubstantial with the divine and the claim that all things that exist in the divine are likewise in the Word mirrors John 1:1‑3 ("In principio erat Verbum… Omnia per ipsum facta sunt…").

section_title: QUAM INCOMPREHENSIBILI MODO DICAT UEL SCIAT RES A SE FACTAS.
anselm_text: uel quomodo sciat ea quae facta sunt, ab humana scientia
vulgate_text: Invisibilia enim ipsius, a creatura mundi, per ea quae facta sunt, intellecta, conspiciuntur: sempiterna quoque ejus virtus, et divinitas: ita ut sint inexcusabiles.

section_title: QUAM INCOMPREHENSIBILI MODO DICAT UEL SCIAT RES A SE FACTAS.
anselm_text: omnis creata substantia tanto uerius est in uerbo, id est in intelligentia creatoris, quam in seipsa
vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s formula that created things are more truly in the “Word” (verbo) than in themselves echoes John 1:1‑2 (“In principio erat Verbum… et Verbum erat apud Deum”). The passage re‑states the doctrine that the divine intellect (the Word) is the true reality of all created things.

section_title: QUOD, QUIDQUID IPSE EST AD CREATURAM, HOC SIT ET VERBUM EIUS; NEC
anselm_text: summum spiritum per uerbum suum fecisse omnia
vulgate_text: Omnia per ipsum facta sunt: et sine ipso factum est nihil, quod factum est.
llm_explanation: Anselm re‑words John 1:3 (Vulgate: “per eum omnia facta sunt”) to assert that the supreme spirit created all things through the Word.

section_title: QUOD, QUIDQUID IPSE EST AD CREATURAM, HOC SIT ET VERBUM EIUS; NEC
anselm_text: Ipsa namque sola fecit non per aliud quam per se omnia ex nihilo
vulgate_text: quoniam in ipso condita sunt universa in caelis, et in terra, visibilia, et invisibilia, sive throni, sive dominationes, sive principatus, sive potestates: omnia per ipsum et in ipso creata sunt:
llm_explanation: Paraphrases Colossians 1:16 (Vulgate: “per ipsum omnia facta sunt”) by stating that the Word alone made everything out of nothing.

section_title: QUOD DICI NON POSSIT, QUID DUO SINT, QUAMVIS NECESSE SIT ESSE
anselm_text: Nam ille cuius est verbum aut imago, nec imago nec verbum est
vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: The formulation re‑works John 1:1’s identification of the Word with God, denying that the Word can be a separate entity apart from God.

section_title: QUOD IDEM VERBUM SIT A SUMMO SPIRITU NASCENDO.
anselm_text: verbum summi spiritus
vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s phrase echoes John 1:1 where the Logos (Word) is identified as the divine principle, here rendered as “the word of the supreme spirit.”

section_title: QUOD IDEM VERBUM SIT A SUMMO SPIRITU NASCENDO.
anselm_text: creator de creatore, summum de summo
vulgate_text: Omnia per ipsum facta sunt: et sine ipso factum est nihil, quod factum est.
llm_explanation: The wording parallels John 1:3 “per ipsum facta sunt omnia” – all things were made by the Creator through the Creator, expressed by Anselm as “creator from creator, the highest from the highest.”

section_title: QUOD VERISSIME ILLE SIT PARENS ET ILLUD PROLES.
anselm_text: Si ergo uerbum summi spiritus sic est omnino ex ipsius sola essentia, et sic singulariter est illi simile, ut nulla proles sic sit omnino ex sola parentis essentia, aut sic similis parenti
vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s description of the "verbum summi spiritus" as existing wholly from the essence of the supreme spirit mirrors John 1:1‑3, where the Word is identified with God’s very being and all things are made through Him.

section_title: QUOD VERISSIME ILLE SIT PARENS ET ILLUD PROLES.
anselm_text: quodsi conuenientissime dicitur nasci, et tam simile est illi de quo nascitur: cur aestimetur simile quasi proles parenti
vulgate_text: et ait: Faciamus hominem ad imaginem et similitudinem nostram: et praesit piscibus maris, et volatilibus caeli, et bestiis, universaeque terrae, omnique reptili, quod movetur in terra.
llm_explanation: The passage’s emphasis on the offspring being “simile quasi proles parenti” echoes Genesis 1:26‑27, where humanity is created “in our image, after our likeness.”

section_title: QUOD ILLE VERISSIME GIGNAT, ILLUD GIGNATUR.
anselm_text: summi spiritus est uerissime gignere, et uerbi eius uerissime gigni
vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: Echoes the Trinitarian doctrine that the Father (here expressed as the "summus spiritus") begets the Son, the "Verbum" (Word), as articulated in John 1:1‑3 ("In principio erat Verbum… et Verbum erat apud Deum…").

section_title: RETRACTATIO COMMUNIONIS AMBORUM ET PROPRIETATUM SINGULORUM.
anselm_text: Nam sic est alius pater, alius filius, ut cum ambos dixerim, uideam me duos dixisse; et sic est idipsum, quod est et pater et filius, ut non intelligam quid duos dixerim. ... non sunt duo patres aut duo filii sed unus pater et unus filius
vulgate_text: Ego et Pater unum sumus.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s claim that the Father and the Son are not two distinct persons but one mirrors John 10:30 “Ego et Pater unum sumus” (I and the Father are one).

section_title: QUOMODO ALTER ALTERIUS SIT ESSENTIA.
anselm_text: ut non per alienam sed per suam essentiam sit, per suam sapientiam sapiat, per suam uitam uiuat
vulgate_text: Sicut enim Pater habet vitam in semetipso, sic dedit et Filio habere vitam in semetipso:
llm_explanation: The clause expands the John 5:26 quotation, restating the idea that the Son possesses life, essence and wisdom in himself, not from another source.

section_title: QUOD APTIUS DICI POSSIT FILIUS ESSENTIA PATRIS QUAM PATER FILII;
anselm_text: filio patris uirtus et sapientia seu ueritas, et iustitia
vulgate_text: ipsis autem vocatis Judaeis, atque Graecis Christum Dei virtutem, et Dei sapientia:
llm_explanation: Anselm’s list of “virtus (power) and sapientia (wisdom) … ueritas (truth) and iustitia (justice)” mirrors Paul’s description of the Son as “the power of God and the wisdom of God” (1 Cor 1:24).

section_title: QUOD APTIUS DICI POSSIT FILIUS ESSENTIA PATRIS QUAM PATER FILII;
anselm_text: filius est essentia patris
vulgate_text: Ego et Pater unum sumus.
llm_explanation: The claim that the Son is the very essence of the Father echoes Jesus’ statement “I and the Father are one” (John 10:30).

section_title: QUOMODO QUAEDAM EX IIS QUAE SIC PROFERUNTUR, ALITER QUOQUE POSSINT
anselm_text: filium esse uerum uerbum
vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s formula mirrors John 1:1‑14 where the Son is identified as the true “Verbum” (Word) of God.

section_title: QUOD FILIUS SIT INTELLIGENTIA INTELLIGENTIAE ET VERITAS VERITATIS
anselm_text: substantia patris est intelligentia et scientia et sapientia et ueritas, consequenter colligitur quia sicut filius est intelligentia et scientia et sapientia et ueritas
vulgate_text: implevitque eum spiritu Dei, sapientia et intelligentia, et scientia et omni doctrina,

section_title: QUOD FILIUS SIT INTELLIGENTIA INTELLIGENTIAE ET VERITAS VERITATIS
anselm_text: si ipsa substantia patris est intelligentia et scientia et sapientia et ueritas
vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s description of the Father’s substance as intelligence, knowledge, wisdom and truth mirrors the prologue of John (1:1‑3) where the Logos (the Word) is presented as the source of all being and truth.

section_title: QUOD FILIUS SIT INTELLIGENTIA INTELLIGENTIAE ET VERITAS VERITATIS
anselm_text: ueritas
vulgate_text: Dicit ei Jesus: Ego sum via, et veritas, et vita. Nemo venit ad Patrem, nisi per me.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s emphasis on truth (ueritas) as an essential attribute of both Father and Son resonates with Jesus’ self‑identification as “the truth” in John 14:6.

section_title: QUOD IN MEMORIA INTELLIGATUR PATER, SICUT IN INTELLIGENTIA FILIUS;
anselm_text: quoniam de memoria nasci verbum uidetur
vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s claim that the Word (verbum) is generated from memory echoes John 1:1‑3, where the Logos is presented as eternally existing with the Father and becoming flesh; the passage treats the Son as the intelligible offspring of the Father’s memory.

section_title: QUOD SUMMUS SPIRITUS SE AMET.
anselm_text: mutui amoris affectum
vulgate_text: Carissimi, diligamus nos invicem: quia caritas ex Deo est. Et omnis qui diligit, ex Deo natus est, et cognoscit Deum.
llm_explanation: The emphasis on a reciprocal love (“love one another”) reflects the central theme of 1 John 4:7‑8, where the author exhorts believers to “habete caritatem invicem” because love originates from God.

section_title: QUOD SUMMUS SPIRITUS SE AMET.
anselm_text: summus spiritus se amare, sicut sui meminit et se intelligit
vulgate_text: Qui non diligit, non novit Deum: quoniam Deus caritas est.
llm_explanation: The notion that the highest spirit loves itself mirrors the biblical declaration “Deus caritas est” (1 John 4:8), which identifies God Himself as the source and embodiment of love.

section_title: QUOD IDEM AMOR PARITER PROCEDAT A PATRE ET FILIO.
anselm_text: Nulla enim res amatur sine eius memoria aut intelligentia
vulgate_text: Qui non diligit, non novit Deum: quoniam Deus caritas est.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s claim that nothing is loved apart from the memory and intellect of the beloved echoes the biblical teaching that God is love (Deus caritas est) and that love is inseparable from the knowledge of the beloved.

section_title: QUOD IDEM AMOR PARITER PROCEDAT A PATRE ET FILIO.
anselm_text: a patre pariter et filio summi spiritus amor procedit
llm_explanation: The statement that love proceeds equally from the Father and the Son to the Holy Spirit mirrors the Trinitarian benediction of 2 Cor 13:14, which links the Father’s grace, the Son’s love, and the Spirit’s communion.

section_title: QUOD UTERQUE PARI AMORE DILIGAT SE ET ALTERUM.
anselm_text: singulus pater est summus spiritus, et singulus filius summus spiritus, et ambo simul unus spiritus
vulgate_text: Ego et Pater unum sumus.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s statement that the Father and the Son are each the supreme spirit and together one spirit echoes John 10:30 where Jesus says “ego et Pater unum sumus” (I and the Father are one).

section_title: QUOD IDEM AMOR SIT IDIPSUM, QUOD EST SUMMUS SPIRITUS, ET TAMEN
anselm_text: IPSE CUM PATRE ET FILIO UNUS SPIRITUS.
vulgate_text: euntes ergo docete omnes gentes: baptizantes eos in nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti:
llm_explanation: The Trinitarian formula of the Nicene Creed echoes Matthew 28:19, where Jesus commands baptism "in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit".

section_title: QUOD IDEM AMOR SIT IDIPSUM, QUOD EST SUMMUS SPIRITUS, ET TAMEN
anselm_text: Denique si nulla umquam creatura, id est si nihi1 umquam aliud esset quam summus spiritus pater et filius: nihilominus seipsos et inuicem pater et filius diligerent.
vulgate_text: Qui non diligit, non novit Deum: quoniam Deus caritas est.
llm_explanation: The statement that the Father and the Son love each other reflects 1 John 4:8, "Deus caritas est" (God is love), and the broader Johannine theme that love is the essential nature of God.

section_title: QUOD TOTUS PROCEDAT A PATRE, TOTUS A FILIO, ET TAMEN NON SIT NISI
anselm_text: et simul pater et filius non duo sed unus spiritus
vulgate_text: Ego et Pater unum sumus.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s claim that the Father and the Son are “not two but one spirit” echoes John 10:30 where Jesus says, “Ego et Pater unum sumus” (I and the Father are one). The language of unity is the same theological point, though Anselm does not quote the verse verbatim.

section_title: QUOD NON SIT EORUM FILIUS.
anselm_text: parentis imaginem
vulgate_text: et ait: Faciamus hominem ad imaginem et similitudinem nostram: et praesit piscibus maris, et volatilibus caeli, et bestiis, universaeque terrae, omnique reptili, quod movetur in terra.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s phrase “parentis imaginem” echoes Genesis 1:26 where God creates man “ad imaginem et similitudinem nostra”, i.e., in the image of the parent (God).

section_title: QUOD SOLUS PATER SIT GENITOR ET INGENITUS, SOLUS FILIUS GENITUS,
anselm_text: solus ille cuius verbum est genitor et ingenitus
vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: Echoes John 1:1‑3 where the Logos (Verbum) is described as being with God, as God, and as uncreated (ingenitus). Anselm mirrors the language of “Verbum” and its divine origin.

section_title: QUOD SOLUS PATER SIT GENITOR ET INGENITUS, SOLUS FILIUS GENITUS,
anselm_text: solum autem verbum genitum, quia solum filius et proles est
vulgate_text: Sic enim Deus dilexit mundum, ut Filium suum unigenitum daret: ut omnis qui credit in eum, non pereat, sed habeat vitam aeternam.
llm_explanation: Paraphrases John 3:16’s reference to the “only begotten Son” (unigenitus filius), contrasting the begotten Word with love, which Anselm says is neither begotten nor unbegotten.

section_title: QUOD AMOR IDEM SIC SIT INCREATUS ET CREATOR SICUT PATER ET FILIUS,
anselm_text: Quod si dici potest: sicut uerbum summae essentiae filius est eius
vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: Anselm likens the Son to the "Verbum" (Word) of John 1:1‑3, where the Word is described as being with God and being God, i.e. the sum of divine essence.

section_title: QUOD AMOR IDEM SIC SIT INCREATUS ET CREATOR SICUT PATER ET FILIUS,
anselm_text: Quoniam autem idem amor singulus est summa essentia sicut pater et filius
vulgate_text: Qui non diligit, non novit Deum: quoniam Deus caritas est.
llm_explanation: Echoes the biblical affirmation "Deus caritas est" (God is love) found in 1 John 4:8, presenting love as the single, supreme essence shared by Father and Son.

section_title: QUOD, SICUT FILIUS EST ESSENTIA VEL SAPIENTIA PATRIS EO SENSU QUIA
anselm_text: filius est substantia et sapientia et uirtus patris
vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s claim that the Son shares the Father’s substance, wisdom and virtue echoes John 1:1 (“In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum”), which presents the Son (the Logos) as identical in essence with God.

section_title: QUOD, SICUT FILIUS EST ESSENTIA VEL SAPIENTIA PATRIS EO SENSU QUIA
anselm_text: Spiritus ... sit patris et fili
vulgate_text: Cum autem venerit Paraclitus, quem ego mittam vobis a Patre, Spiritum veritatis, qui a Patre procedit, ille testimonium perhibebit de me;
llm_explanation: Anselm’s statement that the Spirit belongs to the Father and the Son reflects John 15:26, where the Holy Spirit is sent by the Father and testifies concerning the Son.

section_title: QUOD, SICUT FILIUS EST ESSENTIA VEL SAPIENTIA PATRIS EO SENSU QUIA
anselm_text: Spiritus ... sit patris et fili
vulgate_text: Paraclitus autem Spiritus Sanctus, quem mittet Pater in nomine meo, ille vos docebit omnia, et suggeret vobis omnia quaecumque dixero vobis.
llm_explanation: John 14:26 says the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father and will teach the disciples, reinforcing Anselm’s idea that the Spirit is essentially linked to both the Father and the Son.

section_title: QUOD, SICUT FILIUS EST ESSENTIA VEL SAPIENTIA PATRIS EO SENSU QUIA
anselm_text: utriusque spiritus intelligi essentia uel sapientia uel uirtus patris et filii
vulgate_text: Dicit ei Jesus: Tanto tempore vobiscum sum, et non cognovistis me? Philippe, qui videt me, videt et Patrem. Quomodo tu dicis: Ostende nobis Patrem?
llm_explanation: John 14:9‑10 records Jesus saying, “Whoever has seen me has seen the Father,” indicating that the Son perfectly reveals the Father’s essence, a notion Anselm mirrors in describing the Spirit as sharing the Father’s and Son’s essence, wisdom and virtue.

section_title: QUOD PATER ET FILIUS ET EORUM SPIRITUS PARITER SINT IN SE INUICEM.
anselm_text: in patre et filio et utriusque spiritu
vulgate_text: euntes ergo docete omnes gentes: baptizantes eos in nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti:
llm_explanation: Anselm’s tri‑adic formula mirrors the baptismal command “in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit,” establishing the same three‑person unity of God.

section_title: QUOD PATER ET FILIUS ET EORUM SPIRITUS PARITER SINT IN SE INUICEM.
anselm_text: Est totus pater in filio
vulgate_text: Dicit ei Jesus: Tanto tempore vobiscum sum, et non cognovistis me? Philippe, qui videt me, videt et Patrem. Quomodo tu dicis: Ostende nobis Patrem?
llm_explanation: The claim that the Father is wholly present in the Son echoes Jesus’ statement, “Whoever has seen me has seen the Father,” expressing the full identity of the Father in the Son.

section_title: QUOD PATER ET FILIUS ET EORUM SPIRITUS PARITER SINT IN SE INUICEM.
anselm_text: et filius in patre
vulgate_text: Ego et Pater unum sumus.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s assertion that the Son is in the Father reflects Jesus’ declaration, “I and the Father are one,” emphasizing mutual indwelling.

section_title: QUOD NULLUS EORUM ALIO INDIGEAT AD MEMORANDUM UEL INTELLIGENDUM
anselm_text: pater ... filius ... spiritus ... ut nec pater indigeat filio aut communi spiritu, nec filius patre ... siue idem spiritus patre aut filio
vulgate_text: euntes ergo docete omnes gentes: baptizantes eos in nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti:
llm_explanation: The triadic formula of Father, Son and Holy Spirit mirrors the baptismal command “In nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti” (Matt 28:19), expressing the same Trinitarian unity.

section_title: QUOD NULLUS EORUM ALIO INDIGEAT AD MEMORANDUM UEL INTELLIGENDUM
anselm_text: singulus quisque essentialiter est ... summa essentia ... unusquisque ...
vulgate_text: Audi, Israel: Dominus Deus noster, Dominus unus est.
llm_explanation: The insistence that each person of the Trinity is “essentially one” reflects the Shema’s affirmation of the oneness of God: “Hear, O Israel: the LORD our God, the LORD is one” (Deut 6:4).

section_title: QUOD TAMEN NON SINT TRES SED UNUS SEU PATER SEU FILIUS SIUE
anselm_text: unus tantum est in summa essentia pater, unus filius, unus spiritus
llm_explanation: Anselm’s formulation of a single essence containing one Father, one Son and one Spirit mirrors the Trinitarian baptismal formula “in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit.”

section_title: QUOMODO EX HIS MULTI FILLI NASCI VIDEANTUR.
anselm_text: pater et filius et eorum spiritus
vulgate_text: euntes ergo docete omnes gentes: baptizantes eos in nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti:
llm_explanation: Anselm’s phrase echoes the Trinitarian baptismal formula of Matthew 28:19 – “in nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti” – although he does not quote it verbatim.

section_title: QUOMODO NON SIT IBI NISI UNUS UNIUS.
anselm_text: pater et filius et eorum spiritus
vulgate_text: euntes ergo docete omnes gentes: baptizantes eos in nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti:
llm_explanation: Anselm’s explicit mention of Father, Son and their Spirit echoes the Trinitarian baptismal formula of Matthew 28:19.

section_title: QUOMODO NON SIT IBI NISI UNUS UNIUS.
anselm_text: verbum … imago et filius eius cuius est verbum
vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: The repeated use of “verbum” (Word) together with “imago” (image) and “filius” (Son) paraphrases John 1:1‑14, where the Word is identified with God, is the image of the Father, and becomes flesh.

section_title: QUOMODO NON SIT IBI NISI UNUS UNIUS.
anselm_text: unus pater, non plures patres
vulgate_text: Audi, Israel: Dominus Deus noster, Dominus unus est.
llm_explanation: The insistence on the unity of the Father mirrors the Shema’s declaration of the oneness of God (Deut 6:4).

section_title: QUOMODO NON SIT IBI NISI UNUS UNIUS.
anselm_text: imago … filius … verbum
vulgate_text: qui est imago Dei invisibilis, primogenitus omnis creaturae:
llm_explanation: The description of the Son as the “image” (imago) of the Father and as the Word (verbum) follows Colossians 1:15, which calls Christ “the image of the invisible God.”

section_title: QUOD HOC, LICET INEXPLICABILE SIT, TAMEN CREDENDUM SIT.
anselm_text: et generatur filius: Generationem eius quis enarrabit?
vulgate_text: De angustia, et de judicio sublatus est. Generationem ejus quis enarrabit? quia abscissus est de terra viventium: propter scelus populi mei percussi eum.

section_title: QUOD HOC, LICET INEXPLICABILE SIT, TAMEN CREDENDUM SIT.
anselm_text: et generatur filius: Generationem eius quis enarrabit?
vulgate_text: In humilitate judicium ejus sublatum est. Generationem ejus quis enarrabit? quoniam tolletur de terra vita ejus.]

section_title: QUOD HOC, LICET INEXPLICABILE SIT, TAMEN CREDENDUM SIT.
anselm_text: Quid autem tam incomprehensibile, tam ineffabile, quam id quod super omnia est?
vulgate_text: Non enim cogitationes meae cogitationes vestrae, neque viae vestrae viae meae, dicit Dominus.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s description of God as “incomprehensible, ineffable, above all things” echoes Isaiah 55:8‑9 where the Lord declares that His thoughts and ways are far beyond human understanding.

section_title: QUOD HOC, LICET INEXPLICABILE SIT, TAMEN CREDENDUM SIT.
anselm_text: Generationem eius quis enarrabit?
llm_explanation: The rhetorical question about who can narrate God’s generation reflects John 1:1‑3, where the Logos is described as “the Word was in the beginning… all things were made through Him,” raising the mystery of divine generation.

section_title: QUOD HOC, LICET INEXPLICABILE SIT, TAMEN CREDENDUM SIT.
anselm_text: nullatenus tamen certitudinis eorum nutat soliditas
llm_explanation: The statement that the certainty of these truths “does not shake” corresponds to Hebrews 11:1, defining faith as “the substance of things hoped for, the proof of things not seen.”

section_title: QUOMODO DE INEFFABILI RE VERUM DISPUTATUM SIT.
anselm_text: de illa secundum patris et filii et procedentis habitudinem disputatum
vulgate_text: euntes ergo docete omnes gentes: baptizantes eos in nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti:

section_title: QUOMODO DE INEFFABILI RE VERUM DISPUTATUM SIT.
anselm_text: summa essentia supra et extra omnem aliam naturam, ut si quando de illa dicitur aliquid uerbis, quae communia sunt aliis naturis, sensus nullatenus sit communis
vulgate_text: in filiis hominum, in quibus non est salus.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s description of God’s essence as “above and beyond every other nature” echoes Psalm 145:3 (Vulgate: “Magnus Dominus, et laudabilis nimis, et magnitudinem eius non potest investigare”), which portrays God’s greatness as incomprehensible to human reason.

section_title: QUOMODO DE INEFFABILI RE VERUM DISPUTATUM SIT.
anselm_text: ut cum uultum alicuius consideramus in speculo.
vulgate_text: Videmus nunc per speculum in aenigmate: tunc autem facie ad faciem. Nunc cognosco ex parte: tunc autem cognoscam sicut et cognitus sum.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s image of seeing a face in a mirror reflects 1 Cor 13:12 (Vulgate: “Nunc autem per speculum in tenebris videmus, sed facie ad faciem”), a biblical metaphor for the limited nature of human knowledge.

section_title: QUOD PER RATIONALEM MENTEM MAXIME ACCEDATUR AD COGNOSCENDUM SUMMAM
anselm_text: Quidquid enim inter creata constat illi esse similius
vulgate_text: et ait: Faciamus hominem ad imaginem et similitudinem nostram: et praesit piscibus maris, et volatilibus caeli, et bestiis, universaeque terrae, omnique reptili, quod movetur in terra.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s claim that whatever exists among created things is more similar to the Creator echoes Genesis 1:26‑27, where humanity is said to be made in the image and likeness of God.

section_title: QUOD PER RATIONALEM MENTEM MAXIME ACCEDATUR AD COGNOSCENDUM SUMMAM
anselm_text: omnis essentia, in quantum est, in tantum sit summae similis essentiae
vulgate_text: Invisibilia enim ipsius, a creatura mundi, per ea quae facta sunt, intellecta, conspiciuntur: sempiterna quoque ejus virtus, et divinitas: ita ut sint inexcusabiles.
llm_explanation: The idea that every created essence, insofar as it exists, reflects the supreme essence parallels Romans 1:20, which teaches that God’s invisible qualities are clearly seen in what has been made.

section_title: QUOD MENS IPSA SPECULUM EIUS ET IMAGO EIUS SIT.
anselm_text: in quo speculetur ut ita dicam imaginem eius, quam "facie ad faciem" uidere nequit.
vulgate_text: Videmus nunc per speculum in aenigmate: tunc autem facie ad faciem. Nunc cognosco ex parte: tunc autem cognoscam sicut et cognitus sum.
llm_explanation: Anselm reproduces the Pauline image of seeing “through a glass, darkly” and then “face to face” (Vulgate: “per speculum in tenebris videmus, sed tunc facie ad faciem”).

section_title: QUOD RATIONALIS CREATURA AD AMANDUM ILLAM FACTA SIT.
anselm_text: ut summam essentiam amet super omnia bona, sicut ipsa est summum bonum
vulgate_text: Diliges Dominum Deum tuum ex toto corde tuo, et ex tota anima tua, et ex tota fortitudine tua.
llm_explanation: The passage’s claim that the rational creature must love the supreme good mirrors the biblical command to love God with all one’s heart, soul, and strength (Deut 6:5; cf. Mark 12:30).

section_title: QUOD ANIMA SEMPER ILLAM AMANS ALIQUANDO VERE BEATE VIVAT.
anselm_text: sine fine amet
vulgate_text: Caritas numquam excidit: sive prophetiae evacuabuntur, sive linguae cessabunt, sive scientia destruetur.
llm_explanation: Paraphrases the famous line “caritas numquam peribit” (love never fails), i.e., love without end.

section_title: QUOD ILLA SE AMANTI SEIPSAM RETRIBUET.
anselm_text: Ut quod “nunc” uidet quasi “per speculum et in aenigmate, tunc” uideat “facie ad faciem”.
vulgate_text: Videmus nunc per speculum in aenigmate: tunc autem facie ad faciem. Nunc cognosco ex parte: tunc autem cognoscam sicut et cognitus sum.
llm_explanation: Anselm reproduces verbatim the Vulgate wording of 1 Cor 13:12 ("nunc per speculum in aenigmate videmus, tunc autem facie ad faciem").

section_title: QUOD NULLA ANIMA INIUSTE PRIVETUR SUMMO BONO; ET QUOD OMNINO AD
anselm_text: et ad idem ipsum bonum est omni homini toto corde, tote anima, tote mente amando et desiderando nitendum.
vulgate_text: Diliges Dominum Deum tuum ex toto corde tuo, et ex tota anima tua, et ex tota fortitudine tua.
llm_explanation: Anselm echoes the Vulgate Shema (Deut 6:5) – “Diliges Dominum Deum tuum ex toto corde tuo, et ex tota anima tua, et ex omnibus cogitationibus tuis” – by substituting “mente” for “cogitationibus” and extending the command to the love of the highest good.

section_title: QUOD IN PATREM ET FILIUM ET EORUM SPIRITUM PARITER ET IN SINGULOS
anselm_text: Credendum igitur est pariter in patrem et filium et eorum spiritum
vulgate_text: euntes ergo docete omnes gentes: baptizantes eos in nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti:
llm_explanation: Anselm’s formula mirrors the Trinitarian baptismal command “in nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti,” substituting “in patrem et filium et eorum spiritum” for the Vulgate wording.

section_title: QUOD IN PATREM ET FILIUM ET EORUM SPIRITUM PARITER ET IN SINGULOS
anselm_text: simul pater et filius cum suo spiritu sunt una eademque summa essentia
vulgate_text: Ego et Pater unum sumus.
llm_explanation: The claim that the Father, Son, and Spirit are “una eademque summa essentia” echoes John 10:30’s declaration “Ego et Pater unum sumus,” extending the unity to the Holy Spirit.

section_title: QUOD IN PATREM ET FILIUM ET EORUM SPIRITUM PARITER ET IN SINGULOS
anselm_text: sicut in illam tendere nisi credat illam nullus potest
vulgate_text: Sine fide autem impossibile est placere Deo. Credere enim oportet accedentem ad Deum quia est, et inquirentibus se remunerator sit.
llm_explanation: The clause “nullus potest … credere” directly reflects Hebrews 11:6’s statement that “without faith it is impossible to please God.”

section_title: QUAE SIT VIVA ET QUAE MORTUA FIDES.
anselm_text: inutilis erit fides et quasi mortuum aliquid, nisi dilectione ualeat et uiuat.
vulgate_text: Sic et fides, si non habeat opera, mortua est in semetipsa.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s statement that faith is useless and “as if dead” without love mirrors the Vulgate James 2:17: “Sic et fides, si non habet opera, mortua est in semetipsis.” The structure and idea are the same, though Anselm replaces “works” with “love.”

section_title: QUID TRES SUMMA ESSENTIA QUODAMMODO DICI POSSIT.
anselm_text: trinitatem propter patrem et filium et utriusque spiritum
vulgate_text: euntes ergo docete omnes gentes: baptizantes eos in nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti:
llm_explanation: Anselm re‑states the baptismal formula of Matthew 28:19, where Christ commands baptism "in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit".

section_title: QUOD IPSA DOMINETUR OMNIBUS ET REGAT OMNIA ET SIT SOLUS DEUS.
anselm_text: cum ille solus sit, per quem cuilibet et sine quo nulli bene est
vulgate_text: Omnia per ipsum facta sunt: et sine ipso factum est nihil, quod factum est.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s phrasing parallels John 1:3’s claim that without Him nothing was made that has been made, emphasizing God’s unique role as the source of all good.

section_title: QUOD IPSA DOMINETUR OMNIBUS ET REGAT OMNIA ET SIT SOLUS DEUS.
anselm_text: omnia per summe bonam summeque sapientem omnipotentiam eius facta sunt et uigent
vulgate_text: quoniam in ipso condita sunt universa in caelis, et in terra, visibilia, et invisibilia, sive throni, sive dominationes, sive principatus, sive potestates: omnia per ipsum et in ipso creata sunt:
llm_explanation: The clause mirrors Colossians 1:16 ("per quem omnia facta sunt, quae in caelis et in terra sunt, visibiles et invisibiles"), echoing the idea that everything exists through God’s supreme goodness and wisdom.

section_title: QUOD IPSA DOMINETUR OMNIBUS ET REGAT OMNIA ET SIT SOLUS DEUS.
anselm_text: ineffabiliter trinus et unus
vulgate_text: euntes ergo docete omnes gentes: baptizantes eos in nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti:
llm_explanation: Anselm’s description of God as “ineffably three and one” reflects the Trinitarian baptismal formula of Matthew 28:19, which names the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit as a single divine reality.

section_title: EXCITATIO MENTIS AD CONTEMPLANDUM DEUM.
anselm_text: domine, obliuisceris" nos, "usquequo auertis faciem tuam" a nobis? Quando respicies
vulgate_text: In finem. Psalmus David. [Usquequo, Domine, oblivisceris me in finem? usquequo avertis faciem tuam a me?

section_title: EXCITATIO MENTIS AD CONTEMPLANDUM DEUM.
anselm_text: quae te iuuent ad quaerendum eum, et "clauso ostio" quaere

vulgate_text: Ego sum alpha et omega, principium et finis, dicit Dominus Deus: qui est, et qui erat, et qui venturus est, omnipotens.
llm_explanation: The description of God as the only one who is “incircumscribed and eternal” parallels Revelation 1:8 (and 22:13) where Christ declares, “I am the Alpha and the Omega… the beginning and the end,” emphasizing divine unboundedness and eternity.

section_title: QUOMODO ET CUR UIDETUR ET NON VIDETUR DEUS A QUAERENTIBUS EUM.

llm_explanation: Alludes to John 8:12 “Ego sum lux mundi”, the biblical claim that Christ is the light of the world, here paired with “veritas”.

llm_explanation: Recalls John 1:5 “et lux in tenebris lucet”, the contrast of light and darkness that Anselm repeats in his meditation on divine illumination.

section_title: QUOMODO ET CUR UIDETUR ET NON VIDETUR DEUS A QUAERENTIBUS EUM.
anselm_text: Quanta namque est lux illa, de qua micas omne uerum quod rationali menti lucet!
llm_explanation: Echoes Psalm 119:105 “Lucerna pedibus meis verbum tuum, et lumen”, portraying divine truth as a light that guides the rational mind.

section_title: QUOMODO ET CUR UIDETUR ET NON VIDETUR DEUS A QUAERENTIBUS EUM.

section_title: QUOD MAIOR SIT QUAM COGITARI POSSIT.

llm_explanation: Anselm’s claim that God is greater than can be thought echoes Isaiah 55:8‑9 (Vulgate: “Quoniam cogitationes meæ non sunt cogitationes vestræ, nec viae vestrae viae meæ, dicit Dominus”), which stresses that divine thoughts and ways surpass human understanding.

section_title: QUOD HAEC SIT "LUX INACCESSIBILIS QUAM INHABITAT".

llm_explanation: Anselm’s phrase echoes 1 Tim 6:16 “qui solus habet inmortale spiritum in luce inaccesibili” – the biblical description of God dwelling in unapproachable light.

section_title: QUOD HAEC SIT "LUX INACCESSIBILIS QUAM INHABITAT".

llm_explanation: The image of God as light that dwells in an inaccessible light recalls 1 Jn 1:5 “Deus est lux et in tenebris non est ullum” – God is light and there is no darkness in Him.

section_title: QUOD NON SIT IN LOCO AUT TEMPORE SED OMNIA SINT IN ILLO.
anselm_text: Sed si per aeternitatem tuam fuisti et es et eris, ... quomodo aeternitas tua tota est semper?
llm_explanation: Anselm’s description of God’s eternal existence mirrors Psalm 90:2, which declares that God “is God from everlasting to everlasting,” emphasizing divine timelessness.

section_title: QUOD NON SIT IN LOCO AUT TEMPORE SED OMNIA SINT IN ILLO.
anselm_text: tu autem, licet nihil sit sine te, non es tamen in loco aut tempore sed omnia sunt in te.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s assertion that “all things are in you” reflects Colossians 1:17, where Paul says that “by him all things were created, and in him all things hold together; without him nothing was made.”

section_title: AN HOC SIT "SAECULUM SAECULI" SIVE "SAECULA SAECULORUM".

llm_explanation: Anselm repeats the biblical formula “saeculum saeculorum” (the age of ages) that appears in 1 Tim 6:15 – “qui vivit in saeculo saeculorum”.

section_title: QUOD SOLUS SIT, QUOD EST ET QUI EST.
anselm_text: Tu solus ergo, domine, es quod es, et tu es qui es.
vulgate_text: Dixit Deus ad Moysen: Ego sum qui sum. Ait: Sic dices filiis Israel: Qui est, misit me ad vos.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s formula “es quod es, et tu es qui es” mirrors the Vulgate’s “Ego sum qui sum” (Exod. 3,14) used by God in the burning bush.

section_title: QUOD SOLUS SIT, QUOD EST ET QUI EST.
anselm_text: et uita es
vulgate_text: Dicit ei Jesus: Ego sum via, et veritas, et vita. Nemo venit ad Patrem, nisi per me.
llm_explanation: Anselm calls God “vita” (life), echoing Christ’s self‑designation “ego sum via, veritas, et vita” (John 14,6).

section_title: QUOD SOLUS SIT, QUOD EST ET QUI EST.
anselm_text: et lux
vulgate_text: Iterum ergo locutus est eis Jesus, dicens: Ego sum lux mundi: qui sequitur me, non ambulat in tenebris, sed habebit lumen vitae.
llm_explanation: The attribute “lux” (light) recalls Jesus’ claim “ego sum lux mundi” (John 8,12).

section_title: QUOD SOLUS SIT, QUOD EST ET QUI EST.

llm_explanation: The claim that God is unchanging and only present mirrors Malachi 3,6 “Ego Dominus, non mutabor”.

section_title: QUOD HOC BONUM SIT PARITER PATER ET FILIUS ET SPIRITUS SANCTUS; ET

vulgate_text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
llm_explanation: Anselm re‑states the prologue of John 1:1‑3, identifying the Father as the ultimate good and the Son as the Word (Verbum) of God.

section_title: QUOD HOC BONUM SIT PARITER PATER ET FILIUS ET SPIRITUS SANCTUS; ET
anselm_text: Hoc ipsum est amor unum et communis tibi et filio tuo, id est sanctus spiritus ab utroque procedens.
vulgate_text: Cum autem venerit Paraclitus, quem ego mittam vobis a Patre, Spiritum veritatis, qui a Patre procedit, ille testimonium perhibebit de me;
llm_explanation: Anselm’s description of the Holy Spirit proceeding from both Father and Son mirrors John 15:26, where the Spirit is sent by the Father in the name of the Son.

section_title: QUOD HOC BONUM SIT PARITER PATER ET FILIUS ET SPIRITUS SANCTUS; ET
anselm_text: Hoc ipsum est amor unum et communis tibi et filio tuo, id est sanctus spiritus ab utroque procedens.
vulgate_text: Qui non diligit, non novit Deum: quoniam Deus caritas est.
llm_explanation: The formula ‘amor unum’ recalls 1 John 4:8, ‘Deus caritas est’, presenting divine love as a single, shared reality between Father and Son.

section_title: QUOD HOC BONUM SIT PARITER PATER ET FILIUS ET SPIRITUS SANCTUS; ET
anselm_text: Quod est singulus quisque, hoc est tota trinitas simul, pater et filius et spiritus sanctus

llm_explanation: Anselm’s identification of the single ‘singulus quisque’ with the whole Trinity echoes the Trinitarian baptismal formula in Matthew 28:19.

section_title: CONIECTATIO, QUALE ET QUANTUM SIT HOC BONUM.

llm_explanation: The description of wisdom that creates all things from nothing directly paraphrases Proverbs 8:30, where wisdom is present before creation and participates in God’s creative act.

vulgate_text: quorum patres, et ex quibus est Christus secundum carnem, qui est super omnia Deus benedictus in saecula. Amen.

section_title: AN HOC SIT "GAUDIUM PLENUM", QUOD PROMITTIT DOMINUS.
anselm_text: et accipietis, ut gaudium uestrum sit plenum. Inueni namque gaudium
vulgate_text: Et haec scribimus vobis ut gaudeatis, et gaudium vestrum sit plenum.

section_title: AN HOC SIT "GAUDIUM PLENUM", QUOD PROMITTIT DOMINUS.
anselm_text: et unus deus "benedictus in saecula. Amen".
vulgate_text: qui commutaverunt veritatem Dei in mendacium: et coluerunt, et servierunt creaturae potius quam Creatori, qui est benedictus in saecula. Amen.

section_title: AN HOC SIT "GAUDIUM PLENUM", QUOD PROMITTIT DOMINUS.
anselm_text: Petite et accipietis, ut gaudium uestrum sit plenum.
vulgate_text: Petite, et dabitur vobis: quaerite, et invenietis: pulsate, et aperietur vobis.
llm_explanation: Echoes the promise of the Gospel of Matthew 7:7, where Jesus says “Petite, et dabitur vobis…”, here rendered as “Petite et accipietis”.

section_title: Section 2
anselm_text: non eo modo posse cogitari non esse, quo etiam potest non esse deus.
vulgate_text: Psalmus David. [Domine, quis habitabit in tabernaculo tuo? aut quis requiescet in monte sancto tuo?
llm_explanation: Anselm’s claim that something can be thought not to exist in the same way that God can be thought not to exist echoes Psalm 14:1 (and its parallel Psalm 53:1) where the fool says, “There is no God.” The passage uses the same logical contrast between the possibility of conceiving non‑existence and the denial of God’s existence.

section_title: Section 3
anselm_text: Quocirca etiam si uerum sit esse aliquid quo maius quicquam nequeat cogitari: non tamen hoc auditum et intellectum tale est qualis nondum: facta pictura in intellectu pictoris.
vulgate_text: Invisibilia enim ipsius, a creatura mundi, per ea quae facta sunt, intellecta, conspiciuntur: sempiterna quoque ejus virtus, et divinitas: ita ut sint inexcusabiles.
llm_explanation: The passage that the “true thing” is apprehended by the intellect, though not yet manifested, parallels Romans 1:20, which states that the invisible qualities of God are clearly seen and understood through the created world.

section_title: Section 4
anselm_text: quod nihil aliud posse esse dicitur quam ipse deus
vulgate_text: ut scires quoniam Dominus ipse est Deus, et non est alius praeter eum.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s claim that nothing can be said to exist except God echoes Deut 4,35 “Tu es Deus, et non est alius” (You are God, there is no other).

section_title: Section 4
anselm_text: cum audio intelligoque dicentem esse aliquid maius omnibus quae ualeant cogitari
vulgate_text: O altitudo divitiarum sapientiae, et scientiae Dei: quam incomprehensibilia sunt judicia ejus, et investigabiles viae ejus!
llm_explanation: Anselm’s meditation on a being “greater than all that can be thought” parallels Romans 11,33 which praises the “depths of the riches of the wisdom and knowledge of God,” a wisdom beyond human thought.

section_title: Section 7
anselm_text: insipiens ille responderit
vulgate_text: Psalmus David. [Domine, quis habitabit in tabernaculo tuo? aut quis requiescet in monte sancto tuo?
llm_explanation: Anselm’s use of the adjective *insipiens* to describe the foolish opponent echoes Psalm 14:1 (and its parallel Psalm 53:1) where the psalmist says, “Dixit insipiens in corde suo: non est Deus.” The passage alludes to the biblical motif of the foolish man who denies God.

section_title: Section 8
anselm_text: intimo quodam odore fragrantia
vulgate_text: quia Christi bonus odor sumus Deo in iis qui salvi fiunt, et in his qui pereunt:
llm_explanation: Anselm’s image of a “fragrant odor” of pious affection echoes the biblical metaphor of believers being the “odor of Christ” (2 Cor 2:15, Vulgate), where fragrance signifies the pleasant, holy influence of the faithful.

section_title: Section 1
anselm_text: non est in intellectu aliquid quo maius cogitari non possit
vulgate_text: in filiis hominum, in quibus non est salus.
llm_explanation: Anselm’s claim that nothing greater can be thought mirrors Psalm 145:3 – “Great is the LORD, and greatly to be praised; his greatness cannot be measured,” expressing the same theological idea of an incomparably great God.

section_title: Section 3
anselm_text: non potest cogitari non esse 'quo maior nequit cogitari'
llm_explanation: Echoes Psalm 145:3 (Vulgate) “Maiorem quam ipse non est”, i.e., nothing greater than God can be thought; Anselm’s phrase “quo maior nequit cogitari” mirrors this claim of an unsurpassable greatness.

section_title: Section 7
anselm_text: negat deum, cuius sensum nullo modo cogitat
vulgate_text: Psalmus David. [Domine, quis habitabit in tabernaculo tuo? aut quis requiescet in monte sancto tuo?
llm_explanation: Anselm’s description of someone who “denies God, whose sense cannot be thought of at all” echoes Psalm 14:1 (and its parallel Psalm 53:1) where the fool says, “There is no God.” The passage parallels the biblical motif of the fool’s denial of God.

section_title: Section 8
anselm_text: invisibilia dei a creatura mundi per ea, quae facta sunt, intellecta conspicuntur, sempiterna quoque eius uirtus et diuinitas
vulgate_text: Invisibilia enim ipsius, a creatura mundi, per ea quae facta sunt, intellecta, conspiciuntur: sempiterna quoque ejus virtus, et divinitas: ita ut sint inexcusabiles.
llm_explanation: Anselm reproduces verbatim the Vulgate wording of Romans 1:20, differing only in the u/v orthography (uirtus vs virtus).
